comment.diff_hunk:
@@ -0,0 +1,17 @@
+#!/bin/bash
+
+###########
+# Run CMS test in OpenSSL 1.1.1 (assume keys and certs have been generated before)
+#
+# Environment variables:
+#  - SIGALG: signature algorithm to use
+###########
+
+set -x
+
+echo "Testdata" > input
+rm -f result
+apps/openssl cms -in input -sign -signer ${SIGALG}_srv.crt -inkey ${SIGALG}_srv.key  -nodetach -outform pem -binary -out output-${SIGALG}.p7s
+apps/openssl cms -verify -CAfile ${SIGALG}_CA.crt  -inform pem -in output-${SIGALG}.p7s -crlfeol -out result
+rm output-${SIGALG}.p7s
+diff result input
comment.body: Well, it does: The result code is the result code of the concluding `diff` command: So if the verify operation doesn't (re)produce exactly the input file, the diff (and the test) fails.

comment.body: `make generate_crypto_objects` changed these files after switching from `undef` (digest) to `sha512`. I decided to check these changes in such as to avoid having to add `make generate_crypto_objects` to all build scripts (which is a viable alternative).

comment.diff_hunk:
@@ -0,0 +1,17 @@
+#!/bin/bash
+
+###########
+# Run CMS test in OpenSSL 1.1.1 (assume keys and certs have been generated before)
+#
+# Environment variables:
+#  - SIGALG: signature algorithm to use
+###########
+
+set -x
+
+echo "Testdata" > input
+rm -f result
+apps/openssl cms -in input -sign -signer ${SIGALG}_srv.crt -inkey ${SIGALG}_srv.key  -nodetach -outform pem -binary -out output-${SIGALG}.p7s
+apps/openssl cms -verify -CAfile ${SIGALG}_CA.crt  -inform pem -in output-${SIGALG}.p7s -crlfeol -out result
+rm output-${SIGALG}.p7s
+diff result input
comment.body: Comment added to code to explain it (-> result of diff defines outcome of test).

comment.diff_hunk:
@@ -79,23 +79,23 @@ static const nid_triple sigoid_srt[] = {
     {NID_RSA_SHA3_256, NID_sha3_256, NID_rsaEncryption},
     {NID_RSA_SHA3_384, NID_sha3_384, NID_rsaEncryption},
     {NID_RSA_SHA3_512, NID_sha3_512, NID_rsaEncryption},
-    {NID_oqsdefault, NID_undef, NID_oqsdefault},
-    {NID_p256_oqsdefault, NID_undef, NID_p256_oqsdefault},
-    {NID_rsa3072_oqsdefault, NID_undef, NID_rsa3072_oqsdefault},
-    {NID_dilithium2, NID_undef, NID_dilithium2},
-    {NID_p256_dilithium2, NID_undef, NID_p256_dilithium2},
-    {NID_rsa3072_dilithium2, NID_undef, NID_rsa3072_dilithium2},
-    {NID_dilithium3, NID_undef, NID_dilithium3},
-    {NID_dilithium4, NID_undef, NID_dilithium4},
-    {NID_p384_dilithium4, NID_undef, NID_p384_dilithium4},
-    {NID_picnicl1fs, NID_undef, NID_picnicl1fs},
-    {NID_p256_picnicl1fs, NID_undef, NID_p256_picnicl1fs},
-    {NID_rsa3072_picnicl1fs, NID_undef, NID_rsa3072_picnicl1fs},
-    {NID_qteslapi, NID_undef, NID_qteslapi},
-    {NID_p256_qteslapi, NID_undef, NID_p256_qteslapi},
-    {NID_rsa3072_qteslapi, NID_undef, NID_rsa3072_qteslapi},
-    {NID_qteslapiii, NID_undef, NID_qteslapiii},
-    {NID_p384_qteslapiii, NID_undef, NID_p384_qteslapiii},
+    {NID_oqsdefault, NID_sha512, NID_oqsdefault},
comment.body: These were set as `NID_undef` following the integration strategy of `NID_ED25519`, which was OK for TLS. If the CMS code requires this to be set, then we should think about that a bit more. Following my earlier comment, I think this should be set to the SHA variant matching the NIST algorithm security level (SHA256 for L1, SHA384 for L2/L3, SHA512 for L4/L5). I'll need to review the code to understand where and how these values are used.

 # define OPENSSL_VERSION_NUMBER  0x1010104fL

comment.diff_hunk:
@@ -34,7 +34,7 @@ Update to use NIST Round 2 submissions added to liboqs 0.2.1.
 
 ### Digital signature schemes
 
-- TBA
+- The OQS signature schemes are now also utilized to drive first parts of OpenSSL's CMS capabilities (e.g., to demonstrate quantum-safe code signing). An implementation of all [CMS](https://datatracker.ietf.org/doc/rfc5652) features is not yet available and will be done as the need arises.
comment.body: Agree, when looking at this again, this is too much text/information. Sign & verify are supported (as written in the README.md).

comment.diff_hunk:
@@ -858,11 +866,40 @@ static int oqs_item_sign_##ALG(EVP_MD_CTX *ctx, const ASN1_ITEM *it, void *asn,\
 static int oqs_sig_info_set_##ALG(X509_SIG_INFO *siginf, const X509_ALGOR *alg,  \
                             const ASN1_STRING *sig)                              \
 {                                                                                \
-    X509_SIG_INFO_set(siginf, NID_undef, NID_ALG, get_oqs_security_bits(NID_ALG),\
+    X509_SIG_INFO_set(siginf, NID_sha512, NID_ALG, get_oqs_security_bits(NID_ALG),\
comment.body: I thought about it, but then realised that this would mean touching the template generat(or) (where these [different] digest types would need to be evaluated/written out at build time in order to fill in obj_xref.txt correctly). Suggestions how to facilitate that very welcome!

comment.body: I completely agree: OIDs should remain as registered. I do not remember touching this file at all and assumed all changes were caused by running `make generate_crypto_objects` (after adding sha512 to obj_xref.txt). Let me see whether I can find the reason/mechanism causing this change (and avoid it).

comment.diff_hunk:
@@ -38,6 +38,7 @@ This fork is currently in sync with the [OpenSSL\_1\_1\_1d tag](https://github.c
 - hybrid (quantum-safe + elliptic curve) key exchange in TLS 1.3
 - quantum-safe authentication in TLS 1.3
 - hybrid (quantum-safe + elliptic curve) authentication in TLS 1.3
+- CMS support (sign & verify using any of the [supported quantum-safe signature algorithms](#authentication))
comment.body: It would be helpful to add a CMS demo subsection in the README.md's [Running section](https://github.com/open-quantum-safe/openssl/blob/OQS-OpenSSL_1_1_1-stable/README.md#running)); just a quick overview on how to exercise the PQC CMS functionality.
